name: meteor
subtitle: Meteor
about: Meteor is an open-source platform for building top-quality web apps in a fraction of the time, whether you're an expert developer or just getting started.

videos.title: Hands-on with Discover Meteor
videos.description: I'm going to talk about some points from the Discover Meteor book, like deploying, packaging etc. Feel free to ask anything.

videos.title: What is Meteor?
videos.description: I'll illustrate the key components on the client (browser) and the server that make Meteor a full-stack framework. This video will provide you a mental map for learning Meteor in depth.

videos.title: Building an Meteor Application
videos.description: In this video I'll introduce the Building an Application with Meteor and Iron Router class.

videos.title: Iron Router Introduction
videos.description: This video introduces the Inside Iron Router class. Get a preview of what's to come in the rest of the class.

videos.title: What is Rectivity?
videos.description: In this introduction we'll explore what it means to be reactive and we'll see where Meteor implements this functionality.

videos.title: Introduction the Livedata Class
videos.description: The livedata package is where we get Meteor methods, publish and subscribe, DDP client and server. In this class we'll start off by looking at how traditional Web applications use the HTTP protocol.

videos.title: Introducing The Shark Preview Track
videos.description: The Meteor Shark Preview Track starts with the new Spacebars templating system and how it differs from the previous system. Then we'll look at how to create and use components. And of course, we'll dive into the internals of Spacebars and Components.

videos.title: Make a Reactive Join in the UI
videos.description: How do you reactively join two collections in the user interface? In this video we'll explore two ways to join documents in the user interface. The first prevents reactivity. The second enables reactivity.

videos.title: Publish a Many-to-Many Relationship
videos.description: Although we're using document oriented storage with MongoDB, sometimes it's useful to normalize our data in separate collections. In this episode, I'll show you how to publish a many-to-many relationship from a single publish function.

videos.title: Publish to a Client Only Collection
videos.description: In this episode we'll publish automatically refreshing, signed CloudFront urls to a client only Collection. We'll use Iron Router for routing and subscribing to a publish function depending on which page we're on.

videos.title: Reactive Properties
videos.description: JavaScript allows us to configure object properties. We can use this idea to create reactive properties in Meteor. In this video I'll show you how to create a reactive property method and turn it into a local package.

videos.title: Waiting on Subscriptions
videos.description: What does it mean to 'wait' on a subscription to be ready? In this video we'll explore the DDP 'ready' message and two ways of waiting on subscription data to be ready.

videos.title: Using wait, waitOn and ready in Routes
videos.description: Confused about how to use waitOn, wait and the reactive ready method in your routes? In this video I'll show you how these work using the reactive WaitList.

videos.title: Synchronizing Method Writes
videos.description: Meteor synchronizes writes that happen on the client with the result we ultimately get back from the server. In this video you'll get some intuition about what this means. Then in the rest of the class we'll dive into the mechanics of how it works.

videos.title: Updating Meteor and Package Versions
videos.description: In this video we'll update a project to use Meteor 0.8.0 and iron-router 0.7.0.

videos.title: The UI.Each Component
videos.description: The each block helper renders a UI.Each Component. In this video we'll explore the UI.Each component's implementation and its new features and benefits.

videos.title: Make a Reactive Join in the UI
videos.description: How do you reactively join two collections in the user interface? In this video we'll explore two ways to join documents in the user interface. The first prevents reactivity. The second enables reactivity.
